discussion.content: Yes, B is correct answer. Thanks for "cnote" for providing such a useful link. According to the link the actual DR and BDR election completed in "two-way" state. but in this question there is no option like two-way state, the next subsequent state is Exstart state.

I think, B.
Before Exstart there is no DR and BDR.

questions.question_text: In which state do DR and BDR establish adjacency with each OSPF router in the network?

discussion.content:
The load metric (k2) represents the worst load on a link between source and destination.

EIGRP routing updates are triggered only by a change in network topology (like links, interfaces go up/down, router added/removed), and not by change in interface load or reliability -> A & D are not correct.

The load is a five minute exponentially weighted average that is updated every five seconds (not five minutes) -> B is not correct.

EIGRP considers the load of an interface only when sending an update for some other reason (like a link failure, topology change). Updates are not sent out each time the load changes -> C is correct.

A

“Note that Cisco recommends against using K-values K2, K4, and K5, because a nonzero value for these parameters causes the metric calculation to include interface load and reliability. The load and reliability change over time, which causes EIGRP to reflood topology data, and might cause routers to repeatedly choose different routes (route flapping).”

Excerpt From: Kevin Wallace. “CCNP Routing and Switching ROUTE 300-101 Official Cert Guide”

choices.B: EIGRP calculates interface load as a 5-minute exponentially weighted average that is updated every 5 minutes.
choices.C: EIGRP considers the load of an interface only when sending an update for some other reason.
choices.D: A change in the load on an interface will cause EIGRP to recalculate and update the administrative distance for all routes learned on that interface.
choices.A: A change in the load on an interface will cause EIGRP to recalculate the routing metrics and send a corresponding update out to each of its neighbors.

questions.question_text: Which statement about a non-zero value for the load metric (k2) for EIGRP is true?

discussion.content:
A

"When using an extended access-list in BGP the syntax of the list changes in that we are not matching source and destination pairs, but instead are matching the address and netmask.
...
This extended access-list syntax can also be used in a route-map for redistribution filtering in both IGP and BGP."

https://blog.ine.com/2008/01/04/using-extended-access-lists-in-a-distribute-list

choices.D: A default-network cannot be redistributed between routing processes.

discussion.content: Use the mask (wild card mask) with network command is used for including the networks with eigrp routing process, not for excluding. I think Distribute-list (option: D) is the right answer. However, we can exclude networks with no network net-id wildcardmask command.

choices.D: Implement a distribute list to exclude the link prefix from the routing updates.
choices.A: Declare router B a stub router using the eigrp stub command.
choices.C: Use a mask with the network command to exclude interface Serial0/0/0.
choices.B: Use the passive-interface command for interface Serial0/0/0.

discussion.content: I Think A and D are the correct answer.

comments.content:
C and D are correct.

I just labbed this up in GNS3 using IOS 12, and the stated answers are corrected. However if using IOS 15, then auto-summery is disabled by default and you end up with different answers.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. EIGRP is configured with the default configuration on all routers. Autosummarization is enabled on routers R2 and R3, but it is disabled on router R1. Which two EIGRP routes will be seen in the routing table of router R3? (Choose two.)
//IMG//
